message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, along with low glucose and elevated ammonia levels suggest a metabolic disorder. Among the options, only Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD) fits with the symptoms and lab values. MCADD is a fatty acid oxidation disorder that presents with hypoglycemia, vomiting, and lethargy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory values suggest a hypoglycemic episode, and among the options, only Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency can cause this type of episode in infancy. The other options are associated with different disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including lethargy and vomiting in a baby who recently slept through the night and has low glucose and elevated ammonia levels, suggest a metabolic disorder. Among the options, only medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency can cause hypoketotic hypoglycemia and elevated ammonia levels. The other options are associated with different disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated ammonia level and low glucose level suggest a metabolic disorder, and among the options, only Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCAD) is associated with this presentation. MCAD deficiency is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of fatty acids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a metabolic disorder, and the low glucose levels suggest a hypoglycemic state. Among the options, only medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency can cause hypoglycemia, vomiting, lethargy, and elevated ammonia levels. The patient's recent migration from Bolivia may suggest an increased risk for this disorder, which is more commonly found in the Hispanic population.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest hypoglycemia and ketosis, which are common in medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD). The other options are not related to these symptoms or laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a metabolic disorder, and the low glucose and elevated ammonia levels suggest organic acidemia. Among the options, only Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCAD) can cause hypoglycemia and elevated ammonia levels. Lethargy and vomiting can be associated with MCAD deficiency as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including hypoglycemia, vomiting, and lethargy, suggest a metabolic disorder. Among the options, only medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency fits the symptoms. MCAD deficiency is commonly seen in infants of Hispanic or Latino descent and can cause hypoglycemia, vomiting, lethargy, and encephalopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia (lethargy and vomiting) and laboratory values show low glucose levels. The elevated ammonia levels suggest metabolic acidosis. These findings are consistent with medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency, which is common in individuals of Latino descent. The other options are not associated with these symptoms or laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting symptoms of hypoglycemia and vomiting, which suggests a metabolic disorder. Among the options, only medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency presents symptoms of hypoglycemia in infants. The elevated ammonia levels may be due to stress or dehydration from vomiting. The other options are associated with different metabolic disorders.
